p: While healthy younger adults generally present with more mild symptoms in response to viral infection, the elderly are slow to respond and are susceptible to higher viral titers and chronic viral infection which leads to progression to severe symptoms, especially in the setting of respiratory viral infections [ 48– 54]. The delayed and poorly effective responsiveness of elderly to viral infection is due, in large part, to compromised cellular immunity [ 55– 57] related to “immunosenescence” [ 58– 60].
